content:
In her paper Distributive laws for Lawvere theories, Cheng describes factorizations systems between categories LLL and RRR up to zig-zags in some shared wide subcategory JJJ. When J JJ contains different kinds of isomorphisms, then depending on which isomorphisms are chosen, this is known to correspond to different types of distributive laws.

However, she goes on to show that when L,RL,RL,R are Lawvere theories, then if one picks out J:=FinOrdopJ:={\sf FinOrd}^{\sf op}J:=FinOrdop, then a generalized factorization system in this sense is the same as a distributive law on L⊗FinOrdopR L \otimes_{{\sf FinOrd}^{\sf op}} RL⊗FinOrdop​R in some category of internal profunctors. Does anyone know if this generalizes to arbitrary JJJ, or is this just a property of the subcategory FinOrdop{\sf FinOrd}^{\sf op}FinOrdop of Lawvere theories, and of groupoids? I am particularly interested in the case when JJJ is a category of spans of monomorphisms.

I don't understand this stuff, especially "in some category of internal profunctors". But can you say the specific conjecture you'd be shooting for? Something like a distributive law between the prop FinInj\mathsf{FinInj}FinInj where morphisms are monomorphisms (between finite ordinals) and the prop FinInjop\mathsf{FinInj}^{\mathrm{op}}FinInjop?

I have just been naively assuming that there is always some sort of correspondence between these sort of generalized factorization systems and so called "relaxed" distributive laws. And I am wondering what fails, if indeed something fails when one changes what JJJ is.

On second thought, what I said I wanted is not actually what I want in this case.

I am interested in a very particular thing, but I will try to see if I can distill it to a level which seems well-motivated.
So my specific question is not what you're talking about? That's what I got from you mentioning "spans of monos".

I think the distributive law I alluded to, between the prop FinInj\mathsf{FinInj}FinInj where morphisms are monomorphisms (between finite ordinals) and the prop FinInjop\mathsf{FinInj}^{\mathrm{op}}FinInjop, should exist.

I think that in the case you alluded to, you just need JJJ to be all isomorphisms, and then the distributive law is witnessed by the bone equation.

For a much more contrived example, I am looking at a similar situation except where there are extra subobjects lying around that aren't properly objects.

Fix some natural n>1n>1n>1. Consider the subcategory subn{\sf sub}_n subn​ of Span∼(FinOrd){\sf Span}^\sim(\sf FinOrd) Span∼(FinOrd) generated by spans of the form nk←mℓ→mnk n^k \xleftarrow{m} \ell \xrightarrow{m} n^knkm​ℓm​nk for all m m m monic and for all natural numbers k,ℓ k,\ellk,ℓ.

And consider another subcategory of isomorphisms between powers of nnn, ison{\sf iso}_nison​.

There is a distributive law subn⊗ison{\sf sub}_n \otimes {\sf iso}_n subn​⊗ison​, yielding a category subison{\sf subiso}_nsubison​, seen as adding the subobjects to the isos.

Consider another subcategory monn{\sf mon}_nmonn​ generated by spans of the form nk=nk→mnℓ n^k = n^k \xrightarrow{m} n^\ellnk=nkm​nℓ for mmm monic.

Then there is another distributive law subison⊗isonmonn {\sf subiso}_n \otimes_{{\sf iso}_n} {\sf mon}_nsubison​⊗ison​​monn​ yielding a category submonn{\sf submon}_nsubmonn​, seen as adding the subobjects to the monos.

So there is some generalized factorization system with L=submonnopL={\sf submon}_n^{\sf op}L=submonnop​, R=submonnR={\sf submon}_nR=submonn​ and J=subisonJ= {\sf subiso}_n J=subison​, and I am not sure if this actually corresponds to a distributive law on submonnop⊗subisonsubmonn {\sf submon}_n^{\sf op} \otimes_{{\sf subiso}_n } {\sf submon}_nsubmonnop​⊗subison​​submonn​, but I highly suspect that it does!

I should note that all of this is going on inside Mon{\sf Mon}Mon-Prof\sf ProfProf.
